review.title: Beliefs in Markov Trees - From Local Computations to Local Valuation
review.abstract: This paper is devoted to expressiveness of hypergraphs for which uncertainty propagation by local computations via Shenoy/Shafer method applies. It is demonstrated that for this propagation method for a given joint belief distribution no valuation of hyperedges of a hypergraph may provide with simpler hypergraph structure than valuation of hyperedges by conditional distributions. This has vital implication that methods recovering belief networks from data have no better alternative for finding the simplest hypergraph structure for belief propagation. A method for recovery tree-structured belief networks has been developed and specialized for Dempster-Shafer belief functions

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text: Shenoy and Shafer [16] presented an axiomatic system and a method for calculating conditional beliefs by local calculations. Shenoy and Shafer have shown that their framework is suitable for both Bayesian and Dempster-Shafer beliefs. In their paper, they generalize similar work by other authors that focused on the spread of uncertainty in Bayean networks [2], [14], [12] and DS beliefs [15], [7]. An important innovation of Shenoy and Shafer [16] was to separate the notion of fragmentation from the notion of conditionality. Other authors previously insisted [14], [12] that factors in Bayean networks are conditional distributions. The aim of this paper is to investigate to what extent this innovation is really significant and what impact it may have on the development of algorithms for restoring (identifying) faith networks (distribution data).

sections.heading: 5. BELIEF TREES AND HYPERTREES
sections.text: Let us now look at a specific class of hypertrees: linked hypertrees with the cardinality of each hyperedge equal to two. It is easy to show that such hypertrees correspond exactly to the directed trees. Furthermore, we can conclude that any factorization in the form of connected hypertrees with the cardinality of each hyperedge equal to 2 can be restored from data of algorithms that restore faith trees from data. This does not apply, for example, to poly-trees.Algorithms that restore general faith networks from data have yet to be invented. The main obstacle to such algorithms is the poorly defined relationship between different types of representation of uncertainty and empirical data. Instead, we assume that there is a measurement value (BEL1, BEL2) that is zero if both faith distributions are identical and positive.

sections.heading: 6. CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: This paper demonstrates that evaluated hypertrees can be equally represented by faith networks, which is of particular importance for spreading the uncertainty within the Shenoy / Shafer axiomatic framework for local calculations. The simplest possible hypertree factorizations of a faith distribution can be achieved by methods of restoring the faith network structure from data, and the evaluation of hyperedges can then be performed by local calculation of marginal of the faith distribution. Another contribution of this paper is the extension of the Chow / Liu algorithm to restore tree-like faith networks for probability distributions to general type distributions corresponding to the axiomatic framework of Shenoy / Shafer.
